blurb.title: Will easy schedule translate to wins?
blurb.desc: Kurt Warner's retirement clearly led to the Cardinals' rough fall from grace last season, as they finished 5-11 after winning the NFC West the previous two years. Will the league's easiest schedule help get them back on top?

teamBlurb.title: Path To The Playoffs?
teamBlurb.desc: There are many trips East in 2011, but even after a five-win season last year, the Cards expect to settle the QB situation and use Pro Bowlers like Larry Fitzgerald, Adrian Wilson and Darnell Dockett to make a run at a third NFC West title in four seasons.

blurb.title: No gimmes on this schedule
blurb.desc: The Falcons entered the 2010 playoffs as the NFC's No. 1 seed, but their ride to the Super Bowl was abruptly halted by the eventual champion Packers. Atlanta looks to take the next step facing a schedule befitting of a division champ.

blurb.title: Ravens finished with Steelers after Week 9
blurb.desc: The Ravens went 12-4 last season to earn their third consecutive playoff appearance, but couldn't get past the Steelers in the divisional round. Quarterback Joe Flacco and the core of the team returns for coach John Harbaugh.

blurb.title: Rough sledding early for Bills
blurb.desc: The Bills finished 4-12 in 2010, the franchise's sixth-straight losing season. The silver lining came in the season's second half, when the Bills won four of their last eight. Buffalo looks to build on that finish in Chan Gailey's second season as coach.

blurb.title: What did Panthers do to deserve this?
blurb.desc: The Panthers endured a brutal 2010 season, posting a league-worst 2-14 record, so it goes without saying they have major work to do. Enter Ron Rivera, whose task to revitalize a struggling franchise is daunting for a first-year head coach.

teamBlurb.title: New era of Panthers football
teamBlurb.desc: Head coach Ron Rivera leads an attacking offense and aggressive defense on to the field in 2011. Seven games against teams, including the defending Super Bowl champion Green Bay Packers, who made the playoffs last year will challenge the young Panthers in Rivera's first season as head coach.

blurb.title: Road will challenge Bears down stretch
blurb.desc: The Bears were back in the playoffs in 2010, winning the NFC North and a division-round playoff game before falling short vs. Green Bay for the NFC title. Will a second year under Mike Martz pay dividends for Jay Cutler?

blurb.title: Midseason stretch to test Bengals
blurb.desc: The Bengals fell far short of their high expectations in 2010 after a playoff appearance the previous season. Coach Marvin Lewis is back with new offensive coordinator Jay Gruden, but the stalemate with quarterback Carson Palmer continues.

blurb.title: Home is where the Browns are early
blurb.desc: The Browns took some steps forward in 2010, getting an extended look at rookie quarterback Colt McCoy and surprise production from Peyton Hillis. There is reason for optimism, but new coach Pat Shurmur still has many questions to answer.

blurb.title: Cowboys will have to earn title down stretch
blurb.desc: The Cowboys' 2010 season began with promise and ended with a whimper, and now Jason Garrett is tasked with turning around the franchise. A favorable schedule outside the NFC East could help turn things around, with just three opponents owning a winning record.

blurb.title: Favorable early slate brings optimism
blurb.desc: The Broncos enter 2011 with a new regime, with John Elway serving as executive VP of football operations and John Fox as head coach. That, and Year 2 for Tim Tebow, are reasons for optimism in Denver.

teamBlurb.title: Broncos Football 2011
teamBlurb.desc: New Head Coach John Fox has the Broncos ready to battle for the AFC West crown in 2011.

blurb.title: Early test lies ahead for Lions
blurb.desc: The Lions recorded their 10th consecutive losing campaign in 2010, but built momentum for 2011 by ending the season on a four-game winning streak. Third-year coach Jim Schwartz and his young nucleus will be tested early.

blurb.title: Champs face Saints in Kickoff game
blurb.desc: The Packers were the NFL's best team when it mattered last season, during January and February. What will the defending champions do for an encore? The nucleus is young, and the talk of repeating started almost immediately following the Super Bowl XLV win.

teamBlurb.title: Green Bay Packers: Roadmap to defend the title
teamBlurb.desc: The Packers had to win three road games to reach the Super Bowl and would like to avoid that scenario in their quest to repeat. Green Bay must go back to Atlanta and has road dates at Kansas City, San Diego and New York (Giants).

blurb.title: Week 16 vs. Colts could be pivotal
blurb.desc: The Texans took a step back in 2010, stumbling to a 6-10 finish a year after posting their first winning season in franchise history. The team has pieces in place to contend, however, including NFL rushing champion Arian Foster.

teamBlurb.title: Houston Texans aim for elusive postseason berth
teamBlurb.desc: The Texans hope a defensive makeover under coordinator Wade Phillips will lead the team to its first postseason trip. Houston faces the NFC South, featuring three teams with double-digit wins last year. Also, the Texans host the reigning AFC champion Pittsburgh Steelers at Reliant Stadium.

blurb.title: Will Super Bowl XLVI include Colts?
blurb.desc: Indianapolis has been a model of consistency in the NFL, qualifying for the playoffs in nine consecutive seasons. The Colts looked vulnerable at times last season, and they'll be tested with six playoff teams on the docket.

blurb.title: Can Jaguars overcome rough schedule?
blurb.desc: The Jaguars had the division title within their grasp in 2010 only to watch the Colts snatch it away. The road will be even tougher for Jacksonville in 2011, with nine games against teams that had a winning record last year.

blurb.title: First-place finish nets third-toughest slate
blurb.desc: The Chiefs came from out of nowhere to win the AFC West last season, thanks in large part to Matt Cassel stepping up and playing well. Now the Chiefs will look to remain on top of the division with everyone gunning for them.

teamBlurb.title: Maintaining success tougher task
teamBlurb.desc: The Chiefs made a six-game improvement to go 10-6 and win the AFC West - the greatest turnaround in franchise history. A young team on the rise, now faces an even tougher task. The Chiefs face six playoff teams from a year ago including all four teams that competed in the Conference Championships.

blurb.title: Will Dolphins survive brutal finish?
blurb.desc: The Dolphins have lost their way since an unlikely run to the AFC East title in 2008, grinding through back-to-back 7-9 seasons. They've proven to be road warriors, but the Dolphins must improve on their 1-7 home record if they want back into the playoffs.

blurb.title: Vikings looking to bounce back in 2011
blurb.desc: The Vikings' decision to bring back Brett Favre in 2010 failed, resulting in a losing record and a seat at home in January. New coach Leslie Frazier believes the window is still open, but doesn't know who will play quarterback.

teamBlurb.title: AFC West, NFC South Highlight Vikings Schedule
teamBlurb.desc: The new-look Vikings will take on foes from the AFC West and NFC South this season, including a game at Mall of America Field vs. the Saints. Games against Atlanta, Kansas City, and San Diego highlight the road schedule.

blurb.title: Favorites despite tough schedule
blurb.desc: A stunning divisional-round loss to the Jets ended what was shaping up as another run to the Super Bowl, but the Patriots will remain a favorite in 2011. It won't be an easy road, with eight opponents that finished .500 or better.

teamBlurb.title: Goal remains the same
teamBlurb.desc: The Patriots got exactly what they wanted last season, home-field advantage throughout the playoffs. However, the tournament ended abruptly in the Divisional round. Now, Tom Brady and Co. will have to go through eight opponents that finished .500 or better last season to qualify for another shot at a ring.

blurb.title: Saints baptize 2011 vs. defending champs
blurb.desc: The Saints didn't exactly suffer a post-Super Bowl hangover in 2010, but they were unable to return to the big game. New Orleans has a favorable road schedule, playing three teams with a winning record from a year ago.

teamBlurb.title: Saints: Schedule will provide challenge in 2011
teamBlurb.desc: The Saints face a challenging 2011 schedule. Playing in the NFL's only division where three teams had winning records, they'll also travel to play the Super Bowl champion Green Bay Packers. Another highlight is a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV when Indianapolis visits the Louisiana Superdome.

blurb.title: Giants' schedule has an Eastern flavor
blurb.desc: The Giants' 10-win season wasn't enough to earn a spot in the playoffs last year, so Tom Coughlin's veteran team will look to take the next step in 2011. An AFC East inter-conference schedule creates some savory matchups.

blurb.title: Jets' schedule has an Eastern flavor
blurb.desc: The Jets have advanced to two straight AFC Championship Games, but they don't have a Super Bowl appearance to show for it. Rex Ryan will look to get his team over that hump in 2011, with franchise expectations at an all-time high.

teamBlurb.title: Gang Green's Matchups
teamBlurb.desc: The Jets' second year in their new stadium features a home game against their co-owners, the Giants. Other foes at home in their bid to reach the Super Bowl include the Chiefs and the AFC East-rival Patriots. The Jets also make three trips down I-95, to visit the Ravens, Eagles and Redskins.

blurb.title: Raiders will be challenged early
blurb.desc: For the first time in a long time, there's reason for The Raider Nation to be optimistic after Oakland posted its first non-losing season last year since 2002. With new coach Hue Jackson at the helm, will the Raiders be able to get over the hump?

teamBlurb.title: The Time Is Now
teamBlurb.desc: The postseason is now the goal after finishing 8-8 and becoming the first Raider team to sweep its division with a perfect 6-0 record against the AFC West last season. This year?s non-divisional slate includes games against four playoff teams, with three of those contests at home.

blurb.title: Eagles' schedule has an Eastern flavor
blurb.desc: The emergence of Michael Vick turned the Eagles into instant contenders last season, and the team hopes its dynamic quarterback can bring them deeper into the playoffs in 2011. The Eagles have a difficult schedule befitting their status as defending NFC East champs.

blurb.title: Road back to Super Bowl well-paved?
blurb.desc: The Steelers rebounded in 2010, despite missing Ben Roethlisberger for the first four games of the season, winning the AFC North and reaching Super Bowl XLV. Ultimately, though, the marked improvement fell just short of the biggest goal.

teamBlurb.title: Steelers will rack up some air miles.
teamBlurb.desc: There will be trips to San Francisco, Arizona, Kansas City and Houston, matchups vs. elite quarterbacks Peyton Manning and Tom Brady and the always rugged home-and-home series with the Baltimore Ravens included in a 2011 schedule that will be exciting and challenging for the Pittsburgh Steelers.

blurb.title: Will schedule allow for a strong start?
blurb.desc: The Chargers played to form last season, starting slow and finishing strong, except this time it wasn't good enough to take the AFC West from the Chiefs. It goes without saying the Chargers need to step out of character and start strong this season.

teamBlurb.title: Back to the Playoffs
teamBlurb.desc: The Chargers won four consecutive AFC West titles before missing the playoffs last year. Now the mantra is clear: Get back to the playoffs. But it will be no easy task as the Chargers' schedule includes six postseason teams and four trips to the East Coast.

blurb.title: 49ers can control destiny down stretch
blurb.desc: The 49ers were expected to run away with the NFC West last season but failed miserably. This year, it's out with Mike Singletary and in with new head coach Jim Harbaugh as the team looks to claim a wide-open NFC West.

teamBlurb.title: 49ers Road Map
teamBlurb.desc: Check out how far the 49ers will be traveling in 2011 and vote on the toughness of the schedule.

blurb.title: Not an easy way to start
blurb.desc: Even with a 7-9 record, Pete Carroll's first season as head coach in Seattle was considered a success with an NFC West title and playoff win to his credit. What are the chances of defending the title -- but with a better record, maybe?

blurb.title: First half littered with challenges
blurb.desc: The Rams did the right thing with last year's No. 1 overall pick by drafting quarterback Sam Bradford, who delivered an exceptional rookie season. Will he be ready to lead St. Louis to the next level in his second season?

teamBlurb.title: St. Louis Rams: Looking to take next step
teamBlurb.desc: The St. Louis Rams made a six-game improvement in 2010, finishing second in the NFC West and nearly earning a playoff spot. With trips to Green Bay, New York (Giants) and Pittsburgh in 2011, the Rams are poised to compete for a divisional title and earn their first postseason appearance since 2004.

blurb.title: Bucs back on the big stage
blurb.desc: Tampa Bay surprised everyone last year with a 10-win season that nearly led to a playoff berth. The Bucs have winnable road games this season against the 49ers, Vikings and Titans. They face big tests against division-winners Chicago in London and Indianapolis at home on "Monday Night Football."

blurb.title: Can we call him CJ2K again?
blurb.desc: It's a time of change in Tennessee with Mike Munchak in, Jeff Fisher out, and Vince Young likely gone as well. Chris Johnson has a chance to run wild, facing seven of the 10 worst rush defenses in the league.

teamBlurb.title: Rematch at Pittsburgh
teamBlurb.desc: The Titans will look to avenge their 2009 loss at Pittsburgh when they return to the Steel City in 2011.

blurb.title: Redskins' schedule has an Eastern flavor
blurb.desc: It's back to the drawing board for the Redskins, who watched the Donovan McNabb era fizzle in one season. A favorable schedule - they play just three teams with winning records outside the division - puts the team in position for a bounce-back season.

blurb.title: Kickoff week filled with 9/11 tributes
blurb.desc: On the 10-year anniversary of the terrorist attacks in New York and Pennsylvania, the NFL has tributes planned for games played on Sept. 11, including the Redskins hosting the Giants, the Jets hosting the Cowboys and the Cardinals hosting the Panthers. Kickoff Weekend begins with the last two Super Bowl winners facing off, then heads into a Sunday-Monday slate littered with eight divisional clashes. Headlining that list is Steelers-Ravens, a matchup we saw three times in 2010.

blurb.title: Vick heads back to Atlanta
blurb.desc: Michael Vick gets his first start against the Falcons. The talk leading up to the game will provide intrigue, headlines and distractions, all of which will culminate in a nationally televised game. The Chargers and Patriots will renew their rivalry in New England, with both teams looking for more after ending last season in disappointment. Sam Bradford will make his Monday night debut against another former No. 1 pick when the Rams face Eli Manning and the Giants.

blurb.title: Nice to see you again
blurb.desc: Steelers-Colts means many things: One or the other has represented the AFC in five of the last six Super Bowls, Peyton Manning vs. Ben Roethlisberger, and must-see TV. Kansas City ended San Diego's four-year run as AFC West champs. The Chargers will be looking to re-establish themselves as the team to beat, and a win at home over the Chiefs would be a good start. Other key divisional games include Giants-Eagles, Packers-Bears and Falcons-Bucs.

blurb.title: Run with it
blurb.desc: Chris Johnson can outrun a defense, Peyton Hillis can run through one. Their contrasting styles will be evident when the Titans and Browns square off in Week 4. The Vikings-Chiefs matchup will feature two of the most exciting running backs in the game -- Adrian Peterson and Jamaal Charles -- and a chance for them to outdo each other. Meanwhile, Rex Ryan and the Jets go to Baltimore, while a young Bucs squad will be tested with a trip to Indy.

blurb.title: Playoff atmosphere
blurb.desc: The Patriots had visions of another Super Bowl run last year, but that came crashing down when the Jets sent them home in the AFC divisional round. These teams don't like each other, which only adds to the proceedings. The Packers thumped the Falcons en route to three straight road playoff wins and an eventual Super Bowl victory. Atlanta will have a measure of revenge on its mind when it hosts Green Bay. Detroit gets a Monday night game against Chicago.

week.byes: BAL, CLE, DAL, MIA, STL, WAS

blurb.title: Measuring stick
blurb.desc: The Cowboys finished strong last season under Jason Garrett, but that was when the playoffs were already out of reach. The pressure will be back on Dallas, and a trip to New England could provide a glimpse of the Cowboys' progress. The Bucs took a big step forward a year ago, finishing 10-6 and just out of the playoffs. Now, expectations are higher, and beating the Saints at home will be critical in the competitive NFC South.

week.byes: ARI, DEN, KC, SD, SEA, TEN

blurb.title: International flavor
blurb.desc: In the fifth installment of the NFL's International Series, the Bucs will host the Bears at Wembley Stadium. It is Tampa Bay's second trip overseas in as many years. A Super Bowl XLIV rematch will give Peyton Manning another opportunity to outduel Drew Brees. The Colts will be in a five-week stretch that features four games against teams with at least 10 wins from last season. Brandon Marshall wanted out of Denver, so the Broncos should be motivated to shut their former teammate down when they face the Dolphins in Miami.

week.byes: BUF, CIN, NE, NYG, PHI, SF

blurb.title: Heavyweights square off
blurb.desc: At the midway point, the Steelers-Patriots matchup could provide a glimpse at how the AFC landscape might play out down the stretch. The Jags and Texans had one of the wildest endings to any game last season, as a David Garrard Hail Mary landed in Mike Thomas' hands with no time left. Can they produce a worthy encore? Other noteworthy divisional clashes include the Cowboys at Eagles and Chargers at Chiefs. The Bills also host the Redskins in Toronto.

week.byes: ATL, CHI, GB, NYJ, OAK, TB

blurb.title: AFC meets NFC
blurb.desc: While inter-conference games come around only once every four years, some matchups are worth the wait. Four of the game's best QBs will be on display in Indy and San Diego, respectively. We also get a rematch of Super Bowl XLII, which saw the Giants end the Patriots' quest for perfection. Baltimore and Pittsburgh play for the final time ... at least in the regular season. Chicago and Philly meet in a battle of division winners from 2010.

blurb.title: Make room for more football
blurb.desc: "Thursday Night Football" debuts with Raiders-Chargers, the first of eight games on NFL Network. Oakland swept its divisional slate last season, but failed to finish above .500. Expectations will be higher under new coach Hue Jackson. New Browns coach Pat Shurmur will face his former protege when Sam Bradford and the Rams come to town. Leslie Frazier will make his first trip to Green Bay as a head coach, minus the Favre drama.

blurb.title: Division races take shape
blurb.desc: The Redskins disappointed last season, including a 2-6 mark at FedEx Field. Improving at home and against the division are both musts. This week's matchup vs. the rival Cowboys is an opportunity to do both. DeSean Jackson's Miracle at the New Meadowlands helped the Eagles win the NFC East. Will the Giants kick to him again? The NFC West docket is highlighted by Seattle at St. Louis, the teams that played for the division title in Week 17 last season.

blurb.title: Plenty of reasons to be thankful ...
blurb.desc: And the annual tradition of Thanksgiving football ranks at the top of the list. The Packers and Lions get the action started, followed by the Dolphins and Cowboys. The day ends with the Harbaugh Bowl, with brothers Jim and John renewing their sibling rivalry as the 49ers and Ravens play on NFL Network. Sunday highlights this week include New England at Philadelphia, Pittsburgh at Kansas City and the Giants traveling to New Orleans.

blurb.title: Raising the stakes
blurb.desc: As the calendar turns to December, the playoffs will be within sight. When it comes to postseason atmosphere in the regular season, Colts-Patriots fits the bill. These rivals, led by Peyton Manning and Tom Brady, will meet for the ninth consecutive season. Elsewhere, the Rams visit San Francisco. St. Louis struggled on the road last season, finishing 2-6. Beating a divisional rival in its own building would make a statement.

blurb.title: Not-so-welcoming party
blurb.desc: Jay Cutler's return to Denver will dominate headlines when the Bears face the Broncos. How much will the fans be ready to make their feelings heard about their former QB? How will Cutler respond? Stay tuned. Last time the Giants went to Dallas, they left with a victory and ended Tony Romo's season. With a return to the playoffs potentially hanging in the balance, the Cowboys will get a chance to help their cause against the rival Giants.

blurb.title: Playoff push
blurb.desc: Three matchups feature playoff teams from a year ago: Jets at Eagles, Packers at Chiefs and, in a postseason rematch, Seahawks at Bears. Any stumble this late could be the difference between making the playoffs and going home early. Other crucial games include Cowboys-Bucs (on NFL Network), Ravens-Chargers and Redskins-Giants. Meanwhile, Chris Johnson faces the Colts, one of last season's 10 worst rush defenses. Will CJ2K be on record pace this late in the season?

blurb.title: Lines of division
blurb.desc: Ten divisional games highlight an important week, with the NFL's oldest rivalry taking center stage on Christmas night. The Bears claimed the NFC North crown a year ago, but Green Bay got the last laugh, winning the NFC title game in Chicago and capturing its fourth Lombardi Trophy. What will be at stake this time around? Other key divisional matchups include Texans-Colts, Raiders-Chiefs, Eagles-Cowboys, 49ers-Seahawks and Falcons-Saints.

blurb.title: Win or go home
blurb.desc: For the second consecutive season, the final weekend features 16 divisional clashes. There are sure to be playoff spots at stakes, with a game like Tampa Bay at Atlanta potentially deciding a division title. The same holds true for Cowboys-Giants, 49ers-Rams, Chargers-Raiders and Seahawks-Cardinals. And with 16 weeks in the books, we could wind up focused on an unlikely matchup with even more at stake. Either way, plenty will be on the line to close the regular season.

matchup.title: Divisional Games
matchup.desc: Six games (one each home and away) vs. a team's three divisional opponents.

matchup.title: Intra-Conference Rotation
matchup.desc: Four games (two home, two away) vs. teams from another division, by rotation, within a team's conference.

matchup.title: Inter-Conference Rotation
matchup.desc: Four games (two home, two away) vs. teams from another division, by rotation, from the opposite conference.

matchup.title: Standings-Based Matchups
matchup.desc: Two games (one home, one away) vs. teams with the same standing from the two remaining divisions within a team's conference.
